Situation1: They are expected to be present at a family dinner or small gathering.
Expectation2: Participate in project planning and provide accurate time estimates
Situation2: A binding client contract cannot be finalized until they provide precise effort estimates
Story: I stared at my phone, the group chat buzzing with messages from my family. Mom had sent another reminder about tonight’s dinner—Dad’s birthday, everyone was expected. I could almost hear her voice, warm but firm, “It means a lot to your father.” I wanted to be there, to laugh with my siblings, to see Dad’s smile when we brought out the cake. But my laptop screen glared back at me, the project timeline blinking in my calendar. My manager’s email was marked urgent: “We need your estimates before the client call tomorrow. The contract depends on it.” I knew the team was waiting on me, and any delay could cost us the deal. My mind raced, torn between the comfort of home and the weight of responsibility at work. I felt the pressure mounting from both sides—my family’s expectation for togetherness, my team’s need for my expertise. My heart ached as I realized I couldn’t be fully present in both worlds at once.
